request_pathways.name: HIPAA Authorization for Release of Health Information (.doc)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient must download an orphaned Word document found only via web search, complete a generic third-party release authorization, and figure out submission independently with no instructions provided.

red_flags: Social Security Number requested — unnecessary for records release and creates data security risk
No submission instructions provided — no address, fax, email, or portal link on the form
Form last modified January 2009 — predates HITECH Act, 21st Century Cures Act, and Information Blocking Rule
Confusing ALL-CAPS Item 6 restriction on discussing health information, with typo
bright_spots: Proper handling of sensitive categories (HIV, substance abuse, mental health) with separate initialing and anti-redisclosure language per NY/NJ state law
Anti-conditioning statement clearly states treatment will not be conditioned on authorization

findability.rationale: Level 1 — Effectively unfindable online: the form is an orphaned .doc file not linked from any website page, with no patient forms or medical records section; only discoverable through a targeted filetype:doc web search that a typical patient would not perform.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2 — Primarily a paper workflow: Word .doc format with zero fillable fields requires print-and-handwrite completion; no electronic submission method is documented (no fax number, email, or portal provided on the form).

content_design.rationale: Level 2 — Confusing and poorly organized: dense legal language without visual hierarchy or section headers, confusing ALL-CAPS Item 6 restriction with typo, and high ratio of boilerplate disclosure to actionable content.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 2 — Patient self-access is not addressed: generic third-party release form requires patient to list themselves as recipient with no guidance; no Right of Access language; SSN unnecessarily collected.

compliance.rationale: Level 3 — Some requirements beyond what law requires: SSN requested unnecessarily; no fee disclosure; no submission instructions; but no notarization required and anti-conditioning statement is present.

overall.summary: ENT & Allergy Associates provides a deeply patient-unfriendly records request experience with an effectively unfindable, outdated Word document that lacks fillable fields, submission instructions, and any patient-access-specific pathway.
